AND
SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW

PRINCE ALBERT N.W.T.

FRIDAY, MAY 14, 1886

The Duke of Connaught paid a private and unofficial visit to the Colonial Exhibition buildings at South Kensington. His Royal Highness spent a long time in the Canadian pavilion, which was intro-
duced to the Hubbard collection of natural history specimens from Manitoba and the Northwest. It is a thousand pites that the Canadian exhibit will reach London in time for the opening of the exhibition. Her Majesty the Queen officially opened the exhibition.

Hon. Mr. Thompson has given notice of resolutions respecting the administration of justice in the Northwest. They provide for the repeal of the enactment respect-
ing stipendiary magistrates now in force, and for the establishment of a Superior Court of civil and crimi-
nal jurisdiction, to consist of five judges, with a yearly salary of $1,000 each. It also contemplates a division of the territory into 15 judicial districts and a reduction of the each a sheriff and clerk of court, the sheriff's salary to be $500 and fees.

An order in council has been passed transferring the following tracts from Dominion control to that of the Government of Manitoba and the Northwest Territory: Saskatchewan Falls, Prince Albert to Carlton Forks to Batchewa; from St. Laurent to Duck Lake; from Ba-
toche to Gabriels and from Duck Lake to Gabriels.

The Kingston Area says: Mexico has just set an example that is worthy of emulation in the way of handing over to justice fugitives on
mands without any mention in her petition. Mr. H. Scott charged with theft having forged paper to the extent of from $1,250 to $1,500 on the Merchant's Bank at Winnipeg was followed to Mexico. The Mexican authorities informed Scott that he would be taken back to Canada if he could prove that his mother would let him take him. He found him-
self in a difficult position, although legal barriers were sought to be raised to prevent his re-
moval the Mexican authorities never-
theless took him over and placed him under the impression that no extra-
dition arrangement exists between this country and Mexico. All the more honor to them then for not interfering to shelter a criminal.

Another attempt is being made to send a party to explore Hudson's Bay. It is not an exploration of the straits that is wanted this time, but a settle-
ment of the question as to whether or not there is a strait between the mainland through the great unex-
plored peninsula between Hudson's and Ungava Bays. A glance at the map shows that this is very likely to be the case. Several large rivers empty their waters into Ungava Bay, the river Kowesh or South river being the largest; several large rivers also empty their waters into Hudson's Bay on its eastern border between the latitudes of 55° and 65°. There may possibly some connection between the two bays, but whether the ice which packs into Ungava Bay will allow of such a connection is another matter.

American capitalists have made arrangements to develop the mines in the neighborhood of Lake Winnipeg. They will take the ore to England. During the summer months, work is to be done, the finest canes can only be grown being only 25 cents a ton, while that on pig iron is six dollars a ton. It is expected that the company already employs two hundred men, and arrangements are being made to establish several im-
portant manufacturing enterprises to supplement the blast furnaces. It is seen that with so much rail-
way traffic that will be sent by the projected in the Canadian North-
west, the smelting works might be established in Manitoba near the mines instead of in Dakota. The Government should do something to encourage the establishment of smelting works in Canada. Iron is generally regarded as the backbone of a nation, and no country has a better supply than Canada. It is natural that Canada, if it does not want to be said for other Sierra Leone or Guinea, should make itself a home for the mining industry. The most skilled emigrants are interested in the following display. We have a wheat pipe apple tree from Alabam whose leaves are in-
tended for making new fashionable dress-
ing gowns. Ragshingles from the mica plates strained by the longest rope from gold and diamonds to iron and coal from the coasts from the Hind-
uks to the coldest cabin woods of the north, peat and turf of different charac-
ters will pour into the Kensington exhi-
bition. Australia will send in her wood and meat, her sugar, oranges, apples, rice, copper, gold and op-
als, tea, coffee, and wool. New Zealand will be much behind the other Australian colonies. South Africa will be the front with her diamonds though, after all the vast array of wines from Australia, U.S.A., South Africa, Ceylon, because there will still be little mitigation of the regret at the prospect of start-
ing singles from the vineyards of the old world to the China. Canada will display her maple leaf, her timber, her model farms and cattle ranches, her fish from cod to cod-
fish.

The exhibition might be con-
ceived as only extensive length. Great Britain and her colonies to pre-
sent all the earth can produce. A world's exhibition could not be more comprehensive or more varied. Such an aggregation is a noteworthy event from a national standpoint. It will bring the nations of the Brit-
ish Empire and of British tradition as tending to bind, more closely to-
gether widely separated colonies pur-
chasing interests even more widely divergent. It will be a grand land-
mark point a gaining opportunity for extending trade by acquiring valu-
able information as to the wants of the colonies represented. Amidst such a gathering Canada will make her name alone. Her resources will be clearly exposed into, and it is hoped that this northwestern por-
tion of the Dominion will be placed in a favorable light. There is no part of the British Empire with greater prospects and deserving of greater attention.

THE COLONIAL EXHIBITION

The Manitoba Govt. May 3rd says: The Colonial Exhibition will have excited so much interest and been so well attended by the ladies of the City. It is officially opened by Her Majesty the Queen. There will be a wide field of competi-
tion, and one third of the human race will contribute to the show. India is not a country but a collection of countries. Not are the colonies any easier to classi-
fy. Canada, reaching as she does from the Atlantic to the Pacific, can fill up the whole space between the eastern stretch of the American conti-
nent. The West Indies are not ho-
mogeneous. But when we come to the mainland, we have colonies. Hundreds of thousands of Canadians and as many more from the Falkland Islands, from which to collect examples of the means by which our fellow-subjects prosper and grow rich. Australia is in itself a continent and contains the sugar planters of Queensland, the sheep breeders of the south coast, who offer almost any crop of any climate, whilst in New Zealand we have a region not unlike the Cape Colony. In the Cape-
town Xmas we find an almost perfect garden perhaps, but equally more striking, and though there is little to be said for either Sierra Leone or Guinea as homes for our own race, yet the climate and tempera-
ture in the most distant emigration are interested in the following display. We have a wheat pipe apple tree from Alabam whose leaves are in-
tended for making new fashionable dress-
ing gowns. Ragshingles from the mica plates strained by the longest rope from gold and diamonds to iron and coal from the coasts from the Hind-
uks to the coldest cabin woods of the north, peat and turf of different charac-
ters will pour into the Kensington exhi-
bition. Australia will send in her wood and meat, her sugar, oranges, apples, rice, copper, gold and op-
als, tea, coffee, and wool. New Zealand will be much behind the other Australian colonies. South Africa will be the front with her diamonds though, after all the vast array of wines from Australia, U.S.A., South Africa, Ceylon, because there will still be little mitigation of the regret at the prospect of start-
ing singles from the vineyards of the old world to the China. Canada will display her maple leaf, her timber, her model farms and cattle ranches, her fish from cod to cod-
fish.

The exhibition might be con-
ceived as only extensive length. Great Britain and her colonies to pre-
sent all the earth can produce. A world's exhibition could not be more comprehensive or more varied. Such an aggregation is a noteworthy event from a national standpoint. It will bring the nations of the Brit-
ish Empire and of British tradition as tending to bind, more closely to-
gether widely separated colonies pur-
chasing interests even more widely divergent. It will be a grand land-
mark point a gaining opportunity for extending trade by acquiring valu-
able information as to the wants of the colonies represented. Amidst such a gathering Canada will make her name alone. Her resources will be clearly exposed into, and it is hoped that this northwestern por-
tion of the Dominion will be placed in a favorable light. There is no part of the British Empire with greater prospects and deserving of greater attention.

THE MEDICINE HAT LUMBER COY.
W. T. FINLAY, Manager.

NO LIGHT IN THE WINDOW.

As the train sped along in the night,
With drivers, passengers, as usual upon
The car, the conductor, who was often
Frequently peering out of the window
Into the darkness. The night was dark,
And the moon was not visible, but there
Was a short of snow over the landscape, in
Shape, and yet the conductor looked in
With his eyes open, and he held his
Head in a way that made it seem, too, as
If he were looking out of the window pane.

Looking through the window glass, he could
See the lights of the locomotive passing by,
With a certain brightness.

The conductor looked intently at them,
And then he turned back to the window
Again, with a look of curiosity.

"Ah," he said, "going to be married and
Put the road, going to marry a farmer's
Daughter. Worth much?"

"Aye," replied the conductor.

Further remarks in a similar vein came
From the passengers, but they continued
To look out of the window. Suddenly
The whistle of the locomotive gave a loud
Noise, and the conductor seemed to react
Still more intensely to what he had seen,
Faster his gaze upon some object in the
Distance, then fell back in his seat
With a cry of despair upon his lips.

The passengers gathered round to see
What had happened, and the conductor
Rushed towards the window. Suddenly
He rushed back into the baggage car, and
The conductor seemed to react still
More intensely to what he had seen.

Some weeks ago little girl has been ill
Night after night she was not well, but
This morning she seemed to be recovering
Her health. She was now able to walk
And even run, and her parents were
Happy to see her improve so quickly.

INVESTING IN CANADA.

Large sale at Phil. Lee & Co., Montreal.

Cal. M. Jefries, of Lake Superior, who
Has been engaged in lumbering for many
Years, has just returned from an
Exhilarating business trip to Canada. While
Staying there, he visited several towns
And cities, including Toronto, Quebec,
Montreal, and Ottawa. He was impressed
By the vast forests of Canada, which are
Rich in timber and other resources.

He also visited several lumber camps
And saw firsthand the operations of
Timber companies. He was struck by
The efficiency and organization of these
Companies, and he believes that Canada
Offers excellent opportunities for investment
In the lumber industry.

He recommends that investors consider
Investing in Canadian lumber companies,
Which offer stable returns and potential
Growth. He also suggests that investors
Consider purchasing shares in Canadian
Forestry companies, which are likely to
Benefit from the increasing demand for
Timber products.

He concludes by saying that Canada
Offers a promising investment opportunity
For those interested in the lumber industry.
